stem: A 62-year-old client with an acute MI is on a continuous IV Heparin infusion. Based on the documentation in the Serial Coagulation & Heparin Dose Log, what is the nurse's next action?

tabs.title: Heparin Titration Protocol
tabs.content:
Goal aPTT: 1.5 to 2.5 times the baseline (48 - 80 seconds).
Titration:
- < 48s: Increase rate by 2 units/kg/hr.
- 48 to 80s: No change in rate.
- > 80s: Decrease rate by 2 units/kg/hr.

tabs.title: Nurses Notes
tabs.content: 2015: Infusion currently at 12 units/kg/hr. No signs of bleeding. Puncture sites clean. Gums are intact.

options.text: Maintain the current infusion rate with no changes
Increase the infusion rate by 2 units/kg/hr
Decrease the infusion rate by 2 units/kg/hr
Stop the infusion and notify the provider of the high aPTT

rationale.correct: The client's current aPTT (52 seconds) is within the therapeutic goal range of 1.5 to 2.5 times the baseline (a1). Since the baseline was 32, the therapeutic range is 48 to 80 seconds. Per the specific titration protocol provided in the exhibit, an aPTT within 48 to 80 requires 'No change in rate.'
clinicalPearls: Heparin 'thins' the blood to prevent new clots; it does NOT dissolve old ones.
Therapeutic range is almost always 1.5â€“2.5x the control/baseline.
The antidote for Heparin is Protamine Sulfate.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking 52 is 'high' because it is above the general reference range (25-35).
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In NCLEX, 'High' is relative to the *Goal*, not the 'Normal.' For a patient on Heparin, we want the blood to be 'abnormally thin' (Therapeutic).

mnemonic.title: Hep-PTT
mnemonic.expansion: H-e-p-a-r-i-n is 7 letters. P-T-T is 3 letters. Total 10. (Just a memory aid to link them, versus Coumadin/PT).
